intro: Hippion sexfidum, commonly known as the six-angled thornapple, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Solanaceae, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its distinctive, angular leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant produces small, yellowish berries that are toxic to humans and animals. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often found in disturbed soils or along roadsides. Due to its toxic properties, it is typically avoided in gardens and agricultural areas.
